Every summer the power pack migrates to the Rockies, where the Aspen Institute holds its symposium on domestic and international affairs. This year, MARGARET THATCHER and PRESIDENT BUSH will speak to 400 government and business leaders at the institute's 40th anniversary symposium.

At the opening session on Aug. 2, the President is expected to talk about leadership in the 21st century. Mrs. Thatcher, at the closing session Aug. 5, is to talk about international issues. Among the scheduled participants are MORTIMER J. ADLER, the director of the Institute for Philosophical Research and a founder of the Aspen Institute, and JOHN J. PHELAN JR., the chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange and the institute's chairman.

Following her address, Mrs. Thatcher will get the institute's Statesman Award, given only twice before, to Jean Monnet, the father of the European Community, and Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor.
